awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reevaluating Pre-denitrification BNR for Low Molecular Weight Dissolved Organic Nitrogen and its Impact on Phytoplankton Bloom Dynamics in Coastal Waters
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal waters are contaminated by nutrient-rich run-off that stimulates the dense growth of aquatic plants known as algal blooms. In some cases, algal blooms cause oxygen depletion, fish death, and food web changes that threaten the sustainability of these waters. Significant reductions in the nutrient-rich run-off from urban areas has been achieved by advanced or upgraded wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) that can effectively remove these contaminants. However, despite past successes, many coastal systems still have excessive algal blooms. The investigators hypothesized that the cause of continued growth of algal blooms are engineering nutrient treatment processes that lead to the production of different forms of these nutrients that continue to stimulate their growth. To examine this hypothesis, this research will investigate the potential linkage of advanced WWTP discharge and algal bloom formation in coastal waters, with the goal of developing new and more effective nutrient reduction strategies. This research is significant because it could potentially provide an explanation for persistent oxygen depletion in coastal waters even after significant decreases in nutrient inputs from WWTP discharge. If successful, this research could help develop new strategies for WWTPs to mitigate nutrient effects in impaired coastal ecosystems to better protect the Nation's water security.

The objectives of this research are: 1) to evaluate pre-denitrification biological nutrient removal (BNR) processes, the most common way to reduce inorganic nitrogen (N) discharge from WWTPs, for the formation of low molecular weight dissolved organic N (LMW-DON); and 2) to better understand the impact of BNR processes on suspended algal (phytoplankton) production and composition in coastal waters. The hypotheses are that: 1) the pre-denitrification BNR processes are prone to produce significantly larger amounts of LMW-DON than conventional activated sludge systems; 2) LMW-DON leads to unexpectedly larger phytoplankton biomass yield compared to inorganic N; and 3) LMW-DON selectively affects phytoplankton community composition, favoring harmful bloom taxa. To test these hypotheses, this research proposes four specific aims: 1) document LMW-DON in WWTP effluents; 2) investigate the production of LMW-DON in pre-denitrification BNR; 3) investigate phytoplankton community responses to effluents laden with different level of LMW-DON; and 4) investigate the effect of cation-enhanced bioflocculation on effluent LMW-DON. This collaborative research combines expertise in Environmental Engineering with Environmental Biology and Ecology. This research will employ in situ and laboratory-based bioassays on Neuse River estuary (NC) and Long Island Sound (NY-CT) water to investigate the qualitative and quantitative effects of N in effluents on phytoplankton production and community structure. This research will also explore the addition of cations in wastewater systems as a potential solution for minimizing production of effluent LMW-DON. This interdisciplinary collaborative research will have far-reaching impacts for the understanding of the role of WWTP-driven LMW-DON in both eutrophication and structuring of phytoplankton communities in coastal waters. Furthermore, the project will shed light on mechanisms coupling specific N inputs to coastal eutrophication and harmful bloom dynamics. The results of this research can transform how N is managed to mitigate eutrophication in coastal waters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Estuarine and coastal systems throughout the developed world suffer from algal bloom and eutrophication mediated by excessive nitrogen loads. Efforts to decrease nitrogen loads have included numerous upgrades of wastewater treatment plants from conventional activated sludge (CAS) system to biological nutrient removal (BNR) processes. The previous research showed that pre-denitrification BNR, the most common form of BNR used in the field, may have potential to discharge a larger amount of dissolved organic nitrogen (DON), especially extremely small-size DON, referred to as low-molecular-weight DON (LMW-DON) in this research, than CAS. The issue is that this LMW-DON may lead to a stimulatory effect on algal bloom, compromising the benefit of upgrades to BNR.

This collaborative research, combining expertise from environmental engineering and environmental biology at ecosystem scale, aimed to evaluate pre-denitrification BNR for the formation of LMW-DON and to better understand its impact on the potential and composition of algal bloom in estuarine and coastal waters. The environmental engineering part of this project investigated the generation of LMW-DON in pre-denitrification BNR using both field sampling and laboratory reactor studies as well as approaches to mitigate the formation of LMW-DON.

The study characterizing effluents from various full-scale wastewater treatment plants showed that the majority of DON in predenitrification BNR processes is LMW-DON (Figure 1). In contrast, DON in CAS consists of nearly equal amounts of LMW-DON and high-molecular-weight DON (Figure 2). Furthermore, the concentration of LMW-DON itself tended to be higher for pre-denitrification BNR than CAS plants. These are significant results on consideration that many environmental and operational factors can influence the performance of individual wastewater treatment plants and their effluent characteristics.

The control reactor studies using real wastewater confirmed that pre-denitrification BNR produces a larger amount of LMW-DON compared to CAS, which also showed a greater fraction in total DON (70-80%) compared to CAS (about 50%). Through these reactor studies, we also found that four-stage pre-denitrification BNR will likely produce greater levels of LMW-DON than conventional two-stage pre-denitrification BNR. During the Covid-19 pandemic period, the reactor studies had to be conducted with 100% synthetic wastewater. During this study phase, we found that the addition of an iron salt into pre-denitrification BNR systems can decrease the generation of DON and LMW-DON. These results show a potential strategy that the wastewater treatment field can adopt in an effort to decrease the level of LMW-DON being generated and released into natural water bodies, especially nitrogen-limited water systems.

This research characterized wastewater treatment plants and their configurations with respect to LMW-DON they produce, which is a new research direction in environmental engineering. The importance of LMW-DON in water/wastewater systems and the ecosystem is beyond its impact on algal bloom. One specific example is its potency to become the source of nitrogenous disinfection byproducts, such as N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA), which has received increasing attention due to its adverse effects on human health and the environment. Hence, upgrading wastewater treatment plants from CAS or nitrifying systems to pre-denitrification BNR may need to consider such factors. Collectively, the results of this research can transform how nitrogen is managed to mitigate estuarine and coastal eutrophication, by influencing policy making, wastewater treatment procedures, and ecosystem management.

The current NSF research project gave a birth to collaborations with numerous local and regional wastewater treatment plants. We appreciate their participation in this project and help to collect samples and operational information about the facilities, which were definitely useful to conduct this research. This project also became the foundation of a new research project with a chemicals/biotechnology company, investigating the impact of a variety of organic nitrogen used in pharmaceutical manufacturing on wastewater treatment and its further influence on algal growth in a nitrogen-limited estuarine system.

This project has provided research opportunities to a graduate student who took the lead in both field effluent study and reactor studies and several other graduate students who contributed to conducting this research by helping to collect and analyze effluent samples from various wastewater treatment plants. This research engaged a female high school student and a female undergraduate student from Environmental Conservation major to broaden participation.

Due to the unforeseen pandemic impact, some of the original plans to study our research questions had to be changed, such as using synthetic wastewater for reactor study and its influence on subsequent bioassay. Nevertheless, the project team was able to work around for these necessary changes and accomplished the goal of the research, contributing to advance our knowledge related to pre-denitrification BNR and LMW-DON generation in wastewater treatment.
